title: Generative BI vs.Â Agentic Analytics
text: This guide explains the difference between Generative BI (Gen BI) and Agentic Analytics, with examples, use cases, roadmap, and example architectures.

text: This guide explains the difference between Generative BI (Gen BI) and Agentic Analytics, with examples, use cases, roadmap, and example architectures.

Goal

Proactively optimize KPIs & take actions

title: Generative BI vs.Â Agentic Analytics

title: Generative BI vs.Â Agentic Analytics
text:

Stage
Description
Example Outcome




1. Traditional BI
Static dashboards

2. Self-Service BI
Business users build own reports
â€œI can slice & dice myself.â€


3. Generative BI
NLP-driven, automated insights

4. Augmented BI

â€œIt highlights what matters.â€


5. Agentic Analytics

â€œIt adjusts operations proactively.â€

title: Generative BI vs.Â Agentic Analytics
text:
7 ğŸ› ï¸ Key Building Blocks
âœ… Data Layer: Snowflake, BigQuery, Redshift â€” clean, documented.
âœ… Semantic Layer: Business-friendly metrics & dimensions (e.g., dbt, AtScale).
âœ… LLM Integration: Embedded in BI tools (for Gen BI) or orchestrated (for agents).
âœ… Orchestration Layer: LangChain, AutoGen.
âœ… Action Layer: API connectors & workflow automation (e.g., Zapier, Airflow).

title: Agentic AI
text:
Artificial Intelligence (AI) is evolving rapidly, and one of the most exciting developments is the emergence of Agentic AI. Unlike traditional AI systems that simply respond to input, Agentic AI systems can reason, plan, act, and adapt autonomously. This blog post will walk you through the basics of Agentic AIâ€”what it is, how it works, how it differs from other AI approaches, and why it matters.



Agentic AI refers to intelligent systems that act with intent, autonomy, and adaptability to achieve defined goals. Unlike traditional AI, these agents not only respond to commands but also plan, decide, and act proactively â€” often without step-by-step human direction.
They can perceive their environment, break down complex objectives into manageable tasks, interact with tools and APIs, and adapt their behavior based on feedback and context. In essence, they function as proactive collaborators, not just reactive assistants.
Google Cloud defines agentic AI as systems with memory, planning, and tool-use capabilities, operating in dynamic feedback loops. IBM and McKinsey emphasize their role as organizational actors â€” capable of taking initiative, making decisions aligned with goals, and integrating seamlessly with human teams.

â€œAgentic AI systems are dynamic, goal-seeking entities that can plan and act autonomously.â€ â€” IBM













AI Type
Behavior
Limitation




Traditional AI
Rule-based or ML-based automation
Rigid, task-specific


Generative AI
Generates text, images, audio, or video using LLMs, diffusion, GANs, etc.
Reactive: one prompt â†’ one response


Agentic AI
Goal-oriented planning and action
Proactive, multi-step autonomy



IBM describes the progression clearly: generative AI creates content across modalities, while agentic AI follows through on tasks by interpreting ambiguous instructions, planning multi-step workflows, and taking initiative.
McKinsey further notes that agentic systems assume decision-making responsibilities by incorporating context, risk, and organizational goals into their actions.

â€œAgentic AI combines generative power with goal decomposition, reasoning, and execution.â€ â€” IBM





Agentic AI is made possible by combining several key components:

Reasoning Engine (usually an LLM)

Planner (to decompose goals)

Memory (to retain context)

Tool Use (to interact with external systems)

Feedback Loop (to adapt in real time)

Google calls this an architecture of â€œreasoning, memory, tools, and planning.â€ IBM adds that these systems are typically built with a modular wrapper around a core LLM, which provides autonomy and coordination capabilities.
McKinsey takes this further by introducing a Decision-Making Maturity Model, showing how agents evolve from assistive to autonomous roles.




Agentic AI is already transforming industries. Below are adoption rates by sector and key use case categories (adapted from Bornet et al., 2024):










Industry Sector
Approx. Adoption (%)
Example Companies




Technology & Software
~24%
Microsoft, Salesforce, BMC


Financial Services
~18%
JPMorgan, ING, Klarna


Retail & Consumer Goods
~16%
Best Buy, McDonaldâ€™s, Pets at Home


Healthcare & Life Sciences
~12%
HCA Healthcare, Hackensack Meridian


Professional Services
~10%
McKinsey, Accenture, Thomson Reuters


Travel & Hospitality
~8%
IHG Hotels, Alaska Airlines


Manufacturing & Industrial
~6%
Continental, Fortenova Group


Other
~6%
Various














Use Case Category
Approx. Adoption (%)
Reported Benefits




Customer Service & Support
~35%
12â€“30% faster resolution, 20â€“40% lower costs, higher satisfaction


Internal Operations
~25%
30â€“90% time savings, 25â€“50% cost savings, reduced errors


Sales & Marketing
~20%
9â€“21% revenue increase, 15â€“25% higher conversions


Security & Fraud Detection
~12%
70% fraud reduction, faster detection, improved accuracy


Specialized Industry Solutions
~8%
Industry-specific improvements, compliance gains







Microsoft: ~9.4% revenue increase per seller, 20% more closed deals
JPMorgan: ~70% fraud reduction
McKinsey client: ~90% reduction in onboarding lead time, ~30% drop in administrative workload


Source: Data adapted from Bornet et al., (2024), Agentic Artificial Intelligence.






With great autonomy comes greater responsibilityâ€”and risk.

Unintended Autonomy: Agents may act without proper oversight
Bias and Hallucinations: Decisions may be based on flawed or biased reasoning
Privacy Concerns: Tool-using agents must handle sensitive data with care
Brand Consistency: In customer contexts, inappropriate tone or overpersonalization can damage trust

IBM warns that agentic systems magnify the impact of AI errors:
> â€œA flawed generative response might misinformâ€”a flawed agentic response might act on that misinformation.â€




McKinsey, IBM, and Google recommend strategies to mitigate risks:

Bounded Autonomy: Define task scope and tool permissions
Human-in-the-loop: Require approvals for high-stakes decisions
Audit Trails: Log all agent actions for transparency and review
Brand & Tone Governance: Use tone filters for customer-facing agents
Scenario Testing: Evaluate agent behavior in simulated environments
Collaborative Governance: Assign oversight responsibilities to cross-functional teams





From the Agentic Artificial Intelligence book: - Start with pilot programs in controlled environments - Use hybrid humanâ€“AI workflows to maintain oversight while leveraging automation - Scale gradually while building internal support through demonstrated success - Encourage agents and employees to learn from each other for continuous improvement




Agentic AI is more than just a new technologyâ€”itâ€™s a paradigm shift:

From task execution to task ownership
From tools to teammates
From command-response to goal-driven collaboration

This will reshape work in both structure and culture. As McKinsey notes, organizations must evolve to become agentic themselves: more decentralized, flexible, and responsive.

â€œAgentic AI wonâ€™t just change how work is doneâ€”it will change what work means.â€





Agentic AI blends the creativity of generative models with the initiative of autonomous systems. Itâ€™s already transforming workflows, customer experiences, and decision-making processes across industries.
To lead in this new era, organizations must not only deploy agentic systems but also redesign how humans and machines work togetherâ€”with safety, purpose, and adaptability.
Stay tuned for more deep dives on tools, design patterns, and real-world examples.





Google Cloud. (2024). What are AI agents?

IBM Think. (2024). What is Agentic AI?

IBM Think. (2024). Agentic AI vs.Â Generative AI

McKinsey & Company. (2024). When can AI make good decisions? The rise of AI corporate citizens

McKinsey & Company. (2024). The future of work is agentic

McKinsey & Company. (2024). The future of customer experience: Embracing agentic AI

Bornet, et al.Â (2024). Agentic Artificial Intelligence. Selected pages.
